entry.emph: Order before or after the commencement of proceeding –– Rules 25.2 and 25.9

row.entry: These rules permit various interim protective orders to be made, even before the formal commencement of proceedings. They are intended to ensure the practical efficacy of the ultimate formal determination of proceedings. The available orders include the restraint of allegedly wrongful conduct and the preservation of disputed property.

entry.emph: Interim orders for the preservation or sale of property –– Rules 25.3 and 25.4

row.entry: These rules permit interim orders for the preservation or realisation of property affected by proceedings.

entry.emph: Interim orders for payment or distribution — Rules 25.5 –25.7

row.entry: These rules permit orders for the interim payment of undisputed entitlements to property involved in proceedings.

entry.emph: Usual undertaking as to damages — Rule 25.8

row.entry: This rule sets out the content of the damages undertaking normally required of a person who obtains an order under this Part.
These rules permit freezing orders (Mareva relief) to avoid the risk of judgments being unsatisfied as a result of irregular dealings by a party.
These rules permit search orders (Anton Piller orders) to preserve evidence where there is a real danger that it would not otherwise be available.

Divisions 1, 2 & 3 of this Part apply to proceedings in the Supreme Court, the Land and Environment Court and the District Court: see UCPR r 1.5 and Sch 1 and the Land and Environment Court Rules 2007 r 4.1.
Division 1 of this Part reproduces without material change the terms of the former SCR Pt 28.

Divisions 2 (Freezing Orders) and 3 (Search Orders) were added by the Uniform Civil Procedures Rules (Amendment No 9) 2006. They implement provisions approved by the Australian Council of Chief Justices in relation to freezing orders and search orders.

p.text: [Div 1 am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 9 June 2006]
This Part applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court, the Industrial Court, the Land and Environment Court or the District Court.
[subr (1) am Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 7 November 2008 ; Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[5], effective 1 February 2010]
Divisions 2 and 3, but not this Division, also apply to proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 9 June 2006]

level.toc-caption: [25.1.5] Scope of the interim preservation rules

heading.title: Scope of the interim preservation rules

p.text: These rules permit the court to make orders controlling, and thereby protecting, the subject matter of proceedings until the final hearing of the issues in dispute.
Legislation cited in [25.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 18.2, 25.2, rr 6.1(2).

Applications for interim preservation orders under the present rules will often arise from unexpected occurrences and involve variable degrees of urgency. In particular, as both rr 6.1(2) and 25.2 recognise, circumstances may justify an application for preservation orders even before proceedings have actually been commenced in accordance with the usual requirement to file originating process. And even where a preservation application is made after the commencement of proceedings, it may arise from circumstances that make it impractical to comply with the procedural and notice requirements of r 18.2 . In either case, it will usually be most appropriate to make the application to the duty or list judge of the court. The name of the appropriate judge can be ascertained from the Registry (see also the Daily Court Lists link on the Lawlink Website ( www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au ). The duty judge is, strictly speaking, available at any time. However so far as circumstances realistically permit, applications ought to be made within normal court sitting hours or, in special cases, within ordinary business hours. Only in exceptional circumstances ought it be necessary to make an application to the duty judge outside usual business hours. Applications are usually made to the duty judge in court and, where possible, it is a sensible practice to first telephone the Judge’s associate to ascertain (a) whether the judge is still in court; and (b) what is the most convenient time to make the application. The duty judge will usually find it most convenient to hear applications of the present kind at the beginning, or towards the end, of the court’s usual sitting times ie, at 10.00 am, 12.45 pm, 2.00 pm or 3.45 pm. Allocation of urgent matters to these times is likely to causes the least disruption to other matters that may be being heard. But applications may be made at any time if urgency so requires. See Practice Note SC Eq 8 (reproduced at [SC Eq 8] in vol 2) for procedures in relation to urgent matters in the Equity Division.
Legislation cited in [25.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 18.2, r 25.2(1).

As r 25.2(1) states, the court's powers to make preservation orders before the formal commencement of proceedings are predicated on the existence of a degree of urgency. The degree of urgency of the matter, and sometimes the nature of the issues in dispute, will often mean that it is not practicable to give prior notice of the application to the proposed defendant. Similarly, circumstances that arise after the commencement of proceedings, may require an urgent application to be made under this Part. In both cases it may be either necessary or appropriate for the application to be made without notice to the other party. However, it should be borne in mind that, unless there is a real need for urgency, it is generally essential to give notice of any application to all of the parties who may be affected by the orders sought: see UCPR r 18.2 ; Moat Housing Group South Ltd v Harris [2006] QB 606; [2005] 4 All ER 1051; [2005] EWCA Civ 287 at [63] and [71] (order without notice is an exceptional remedy –– must be necessary and in proportion to the harm to be avoided — inappropriate to make ex parte eviction type orders).
Legislation cited in [25.1.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.2(3), r 6.1.

It is highly desirable that a draft originating process be prepared setting out the particular orders sought. An applicant must, in any event, give and comply with an undertaking to file an originating process within 48 hours of the granting of the application, or within such further time as the court directs: UCPR r 25.2(3) . (If the application is refused the applicant cannot take any step in the court until originating process is filed in compliance with UCPR r 6.1 . See however [25.1.80] ).

level.toc-caption: [25.1.25] Documents and evidence –– to support the application

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.1.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 75.

heading.title: Documents and evidence –– to support the application

p.text: The application should be supported by appropriate affidavit evidence. The court may rely upon oral statements made by the legal representatives in urgent situations where it not possible to prepare affidavits. However, the requirement of utmost candour, the possibility of unintentional error, and the possible consequences for both parties if interlocutory relief is wrongly obtained, suggest the clear desirability of affidavit evidence being provided.

The prospect of obtaining the interim relief sought will be enhanced if the application is supported by affidavit evidence in proper form and contains evidence that would be admissible at a final hearing. However, the urgent circumstances in which the need for relief can arise often mean that obtaining admissible first hand evidence is either impracticable or impossible in the circumstances. Hearsay statements are admissible on interlocutory applications — provided the source of the information is provided: Evidence Act 1995 s 75 . Furthermore, the criterion of admissibility on an application for an interlocutory injunction is whether the applicant has established a “prima facie” case with sufficient probability of success: see [25.1.45] . In assessing that question the court can take into account the evidence that may ultimately be available to the parties at the final hearing. Evidence may be admissible at an interlocutory stage of the proceedings because of its tendency to show the party’s capacity to prove a fact at a final hearing – even if the evidence would not itself be admissible as directly probative of that fact: Geoffrey W Hill & Associates v King (1992) 27 NSWLR 228 ; Bird v Lake (1863) 1 H & M 111 at 118; 71 ER 49 at 52.

level.toc-caption: [25.1.30] Ex parte applications — lack of candour in disclosing material facts

heading.title: Ex parte applications — lack of candour in disclosing material facts

p.text: An applicant for ex parte orders must disclose all material matters to the court. This candour obligation especially requires disclosure of material matters that may be adverse to the applicant's case. The fundamental rationale for the requirement for candid disclosure is that an applicant who appears without an opposing party must afford the court a proper opportunity of “analysing the facts from the perspective of any available case that the party knows could have been put by the party against whom the orders are sought: Walter Rau Neusser Oel Und Fett AG v Cross Pacific Trading Ltd [2005] FCA 955; BC200505075 at [38] .

The rationale requiring an applicant’s candid disclosure applies to a wide range of applications. It is not confined to applications for ex parte injunctions. It includes, for example, applications for:
an order for examination: Re Imperial Continental Water Corp (1886) 33 Ch D 314 ;
a costs certificate: Garrard (t/as Arthur Anderson & Co) v Email Furniture Pty Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 662 ;
a grant of letters of administration: Murakami v Murakami [2005] NSWSC 953; BC200507289 ; and
a freezing order: see [25.11.25] .
The matters to which an ex parte applicant’s “material disclosure” obligations applies include anything that:

is likely to influence the court in acceding to the application: South Downs Packers Pty Ltd v Beaver (1984) 8 ACLR 990 at 1002 . See also R v Kensington Income Tax Cmrs [1917] 1 KB 486 ; Bentley v Nelson [1963] WAR 89 ; Gilfillan v Gilfillan (1973) 6 SASR 330 ; or

could, as a real possibility, influence the court’s determination: Milcap Publishing Group AB v Coranto Corp Pty Ltd (1995) 32 IPR 34 at 35; BC9507722 ; Lamb v Ariss [2006] FCA 582; BC200603401 at [23]–[25] ; and see Kerr on Injunctions, 6th ed, pp 660–1.) This criterion includes matters that go to the applicant’s ability to provide an adequate undertaking as to damages: see [25.8.10] .

Any demonstrated breach of an ex parte applicant’s material disclosure obligation will generally lead to dissolution of any orders that have been obtained: Brown v Newall (1837) 2 My & Cr 558; 40 ER 752; Thomas A Edison Ltd v Bullock (1912) 15 CLR 679; [1912] HCA 72 ; Re South Downs Packers Pty Ltd [1984] 2 Qd R 559; (1984) 8 ACLR 990 ; Town & Country Sport Resorts (Holdings) Pty Ltd v Partnership Pacific Ltd (1988) 20 FCR 540; 97 ALR 315 ; Grant Matich & Co Pty Ltd v Toyo Menka Kaisha Ltd (1978) 3 ACLR 375 ; Re Gasbourne Pty Ltd (1984) 8 ACLR 618 ; Trewenack v Clipper's Anchorage Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Powell J, No 4446/83, 8 December 1983, unreported); Frigo v Culhaci (NSWCA, 17 July 1998, unreported, BC9803225) (ex parte Mareva order — reliance on without prejudice correspondence — order discharged); Walter Rau Neusser Oel Und Fett AG v Cross Pacific Trading Ltd [2005] FCA 955; BC200505075 at [38] (ex parte Anton Piller orders — ex parte orders discharged); Lamb v Ariss [2006] FCA 582; BC200603401 at [23]–[25] (ex parte mandatory injunction — information from bankrupt’s examination not disclosed — injunction set aside). This general consequence will follow even if the material fact has been merely forgotten, rather than deliberately concealed: Clifton v Robinson (1853) 16 Beav 355; 51 ER 816 .

If an ex parte injunction is dissolved on the ground of non-disclosure, the plaintiff is not precluded from making another application for an injunction on the merits: Fitch v Rochfort (1849) 18 LJ Ch 458 ; Thomas A Edison Ltd v Bullock (1912) 15 CLR 679 at 683; [1912] HCA 72 ; Bennett v Excelsior Land, Investment and Building Co Ltd (1893) 14 LR (NSW) Eq 179 at 182. Where there is a contested motion for further orders, the disclosure principle no longer applies: Bennett v Excelsior Land Investment and Building Co Ltd, above, at 182; J Aron Corp v Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd (2004) 183 FLR 90; [2004] NSWSC 533; BC200403819 at [18]–[20] (distinguishing Kavia Holdings Pty Ltd v Werncog Pty Ltd [1999] NSWSC 839; BC9905216 at [1] and Elton v Cavill (No 2) (1994) 34 NSWLR 289 at 304; BC9405143 ).

level.toc-caption: [25.1.35] Ex parte applications — duration of orders — “interim” and “interlocutory”

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.1.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 25.2.

heading.title: Ex parte applications — duration of orders — “interim” and “interlocutory”

p.text: UCPR r 25.2 specifically contemplates that applications for interim preservation orders can be made before the commencement of proceedings. As indicated in [25.1.15] , such applications may be made without prior notice to the person intended to be affected by the order.

Where an order is made without notice to the affected parties, it is usually desirable that the order be expressed to operate only until a named day, commonly no more than a day or two after the date of the order (in the expectation that this will permit the affected party to be served and to apprise themselves sufficiently of the matters in contest): Z Ltd v A-Z; sub nom Z Ltd v A (AllER) [1982] 1 All ER 556; [1982] 2 WLR 288; [1982] QB 558 at 577 ) per Lord Denning MR. This practice, of making ex parte orders only until a named date, also serves to emphasise that, in the ordinary case, a defendant does not have to justify the discharge of an ex parte injunction: Trewenack v Clipper's Anchorage Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Powell J, No 4446/83, 8 December 1983, unreported). If the order is expressed to continue until a named day, then it will lapse after that day unless a further order is made by the court: Bolton v London School Board (1878) 7 Ch D 766 ; Broadhurst v Nicols [1902] QWN 21 ; In the Marriage of King (1976) 13 ALR 401, at 404–5.

However, practical considerations, principally directed towards minimising the need for mere formal court attendance, suggest the convenience of ex parte orders being expressed to operate “until further order”: Z Ltd v A-Z; sub nom Z Ltd v A (AllER) [1982] QB 558; [1982] 1 All ER 556; [1982] 2 WLR 288 per Kerr LJ at 587–8: Moat Housing Group-South Ltd v Harris [2005] 4 All ER 1051; [2006] QB 606; [2005] EWCA Civ 287 per Brooke LJ at [85]–[86] (practice to order injunction to remain in force for 6 months but provide for prompt notice hearing for continuation of injunction). Interlocutory orders made “until further order” continue until they are expressly varied or discharged, or are impliedly brought to an end by the final determination of the proceedings: Fatimi Pty Ltd v Bryant (2002) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-677; [2002] NSWSC 750; BC200205591 at [228]; Attorney-General (Cth) v Davids Holdings Pty Ltd (1993) ATPR ¶41-247 Drummond J said, at ¶41–349.

The choice between making ex parte orders only until a named date or, alternatively, until further order, should not have any real practical effect on the substantive rights of the affected party. That party should still be given prompt notice of the orders made. The orders should be expressed, from the outset, in a form that pays proper regard to the affected parties’ rights: Z Ltd v A-Z; sub nom Z Ltd v A (AllER) [1982] 1 All ER 556; [1982] 2 WLR 288; [1982] QB 558 per Kerr LJ at 587–8. While the affected party retains the right to seek discharge or variation of the orders, the onus remains upon the applicant, irrespective of the form of the order, to justify the continuation of an order which has been obtained “ex parte”: Resort Hotels Management Pty Ltd v Resort Hotels of Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 22 NSWLR 730 at 731 .

level.toc-caption: [25.1.45] Onus for interlocutory relief — usual test — “serious question” and “balance of convenience”

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.1.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 25.1–25.7, r 25.7.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 86(2).

heading.title: Onus for interlocutory relief — usual test — “serious question” and “balance of convenience”

p.text: UCPR rr 25.1–25.7 permit interlocutory orders to be made in a variety of circumstances, ranging from the protection of persons and property to the authorisation of payments prior to final judgment. In all these situations an applicant must satisfy the court that they have a sufficient apparent entitlement to the orders sought: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 at [11], [19] and [20] (Lenah Game Meats). They must also satisfy the court that making the order, including any terms and conditions authorised by CPA s 86(2) , is best calculated to satisfy the requirements of justice in the particular case — notwithstanding any potential detriment to the persons potentially affected by the order (including persons to who UCPR r 25.7 refers): Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428. In meeting those requirements different considerations will arise depending on:
the nature of the issues in contention;
the extent to which the proceedings involve contentious issues of law or the application of settled legal principles to disputed facts;
whether the order will have the effect of determining the practical result of the proceedings; and
the likelihood of material detriment, including detriment to other persons.

level.toc-caption: [25.1.45A] Sufficient apparent entitlement — “prima facie case” and “serious question to be tried”

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.1.45A] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 25.2–25.7.

heading.title: Sufficient apparent entitlement — “prima facie case” and “serious question to be tried”

p.text: The general principle justifying the grant of interim relief is the incidental power of courts to ensure the effective exercise of their jurisdiction: Patrick Stevedores Operations No 2 Pty Ltd v Maritime Union of Australia (1998) 195 CLR 1; 153 ALR 643; [1998] HCA 30; BC9801511 at [35] . This principle itself justifies the fundamental requirement that an applicant must satisfy the court they have sufficient apparent entitlement to justify the orders sought being made on an interim basis: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560 ; Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 at [11] ; Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [19] and [65]–[71] . This fundamental requirement is sometimes abbreviated into propositions that the applicant must establish a “prima facie case” and a “probability” of success at trial: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560 ; or a “serious question to be tried” (the formula favoured in American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 407; [1975] 1 All ER 504 ).

Views have differed as to whether these shorthand expressions really differ in substance: see RP Meagher, JD Heydon, and M Leeming, Meagher, Gummow and Lehane’s Equity: Doctrines and Remedies, 4th ed, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2002 at [21-370]. And there are many instances where they have been used as true alternatives: see Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd v South Australia (1986) 161 CLR 148 at 153–6; 67 ALR 553; BC8601376 per Mason CJ; Australian Coarse Grain Pool Pty Ltd v Barley Marketing Board of Queensland (No 1) (1982) 46 ALR 398; 57 ALJR 425; BC8200143 per Gibbs CJ; Shercliff v Engadine Acceptance Corp Pty Ltd [1978] 1 NSWLR 729 ; Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428 ; and [SCA s 66.10] .

The position is now settled that an applicant must establish “a prima facie case”, in the sense that if the evidence remains as it is there is a “probability… at the trial… the plaintiff will… be entitled to relief”: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [19] and [65]–[71] — approving. The reference to a “prima facie case” is probably best understood as emphasising that the plaintiff’s claim must apparently invoke a recognised principle: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 at [20] . The degree of “probability” of success required involves an impressionistic assessment of the apparent “sufficiency” of the plaintiff’s evidence. That assessment will be influenced both by the nature of the proceedings and the nature of the orders sought: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [65] [71] . But it does not involve any forecast of the likely result of the proceedings and does not require an applicant to satisfy the court about the likely ultimate balance of probability: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622-3; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560 .

There is at least a potential difference between the requirement to establish a “sufficient apparent entitlement” and the “serious question to be tried” formula favoured in American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 407; [1975] 1 All ER 504 . The “serious question” formula suggests the threshold arguability of the plaintiff’s claim is sufficient, and that the discretion should then be exercised merely by reference to the balance of convenience. This suggestion has been specifically rebuffed. It obscures “the governing consideration that the requisite strength of the probability of ultimate success depends upon the nature of the rights asserted and the practical consequences likely to flow from the order sought”: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [71] .

level.toc-caption: [25.1.45B] Risk of detriment and “balance of convenience”

heading.title: Risk of detriment and “balance of convenience”

p.text: Any application under the present rules will ordinarily carry some risk of detriment to the opposing party or other persons: Patrick Stevedores Operations No 2 Pty Ltd v Maritime Union of Australia (1998) 195 CLR 1; 153 ALR 643; [1998] HCA 30; BC9801511 at [65]–[66] . Consequently, the court must consider both the nature of the applicant’s claim, and the competing interests of the other persons potentially affected, and assess the extent to which there is a material risk that either the plaintiff or those other persons will suffer significant loss, especially where subsequently awarded damages may not provide adequate compensation. This consideration is usually described as involving the balance of convenience — though it might, and perhaps more aptly, be described as evaluating the “balance of the risk of… injustice”: Cayne v Global Natural Resources plc [1984] 1 All ER 225 at 237 (Global Natural Resources) per May LJ. As to the factors potentially involved in the “balance of convenience”, see [SCA s 66.15] .

level.toc-caption: [25.1.45C] Applications having the practical effect of determining the proceedings

heading.title: Applications having the practical effect of determining the proceedings

p.text: Where the grant or refusal of the application will have the practical effect of putting an end to the proceedings, the court should approach the case on the broad principle of avoiding injustice by balancing the risks of injustice to either party: Global Natural Resources ; NWL Ltd v Woods [1979] 3 All ER 614 at 625–6; Astro Exito Navegacion SA v Southland Enterprise Co Ltd (No 2) [1982] QB 1248 . That process will necessarily involve some evaluation of the apparent strength of the plaintiff's claim for final relief, and an assessment of the degree of injustice that may result from an order that will have the practical result of depriving the defendant of its ordinary right to contest the claim in a final hearing: Kolback Securities Ltd v Epoch Mining NL (1987) 8 NSWLR 533 at 536; 11 ACLR 630; Lenah Game Meats at CLR 219; Fayad v Bellpac Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 755; BC200405241 ; Brayson Motors Pty Ltd v Federal Cmr of Taxation (1983) 46 ALR 279 at 285 (apparent strength of the applicant’s case is the “chief factor”); Active Leisure (Sports) Pty Ltd v Sportsman’s Australia Ltd [1991] 1 Qd R 301 at 314 (mandatory injunction — "high degree of assurance" required).

level.toc-caption: [25.1.45D] Applications involving disputed questions of law

heading.title: Applications involving disputed questions of law

p.text: Where the applicant’s substantive claim in the proceedings depends on the determination of a question of law, it may sometimes be appropriate to decide that question on the interlocutory application: Lenah Game Meats at [19]. Whether or not it is appropriate to do so will depend on:
the nature of the question, particularly either its novelty or apparent difficulty;
whether the question can be properly determined on the presently available evidence, and

whether the circumstances, including the urgency of the matter, make it practicable to give the matter proper consideration: AG v Hayden (No 1) (1984) 56 ALR 73 at 79; Cohen v Peko-Wallsend (1986) 68 ALR 394 at 397; 61 ALJR 57; BC8601388 .

level.toc-caption: [25.1.45E] Applications involving disputed questions of fact

heading.title: Applications involving disputed questions of fact

p.text: Where the applicant’s substantive claim in the proceedings depends on the determination of disputed factual issues it will not be appropriate for the court to either decide or forecast the likely decision on, those issues. The court should proceed to assess the sufficiency of the applicant’s apparent entitlement and the “balance of convenience”: Kolback Securities Ltd v Epoch Mining NL (1987) 8 NSWLR 533 at 535; 11 ACLR 630.

The power to grant an injunction to restrain publication of alleged defamatory material is exercised on the same principled basis as any other interlocutory injunction: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [16]–[19], [65]–[71], [73]–[82], especially [75] and [78] . However, the nature of the issues in, and the public interests relating to, defamation proceedings require particular attention to both the “sufficiency” of the plaintiff’s apparent “probability” of success and questions of the balance of convenience.

The public interest in freedom of expression is a particularly important consideration in assessing the “sufficiency” of the plaintiff’s claim. This is because there is a general reluctance to restrain publication of matters of legitimate public interest: Greene v Associated Newspapers Ltd [2005] QB 972; [2005] 1 All ER 30; [2004] EWCA Civ 1462 ; Church of Scientology of California v Reader's Digest Services Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 344 ; Hubbard v Vosper [1972] 2 QB 84 at 97 ; Edelsten v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1978] 1 NSWLR 685 ; Healy v Askin [1974] 1 NSWLR 436 ; Harper v Whitby [1978] 1 NSWLR 35 .

That public interest properly informs the application of the general principles relating to the grant of interlocutory injunctions. Those general principles properly require recognition of a degree of flexibility: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O’Neill (2006) 227 CLR 57; 229 ALR 457; [2006] HCA 46; BC200607692 at [18] and [78] (explaining Chappell v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 153 ). But the position remains that the legitimate public interest in free speech, and long established precedent, require considerable caution before restraining allegedly defamatory publications: Stocker v McElhinney (No 2) [1961] NSWR 1043; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 541 at 543–4 . In order to establish a proper claim for such an injunction a plaintiff must generally show that:
the impugned publication was unarguably defamatory;

there is no real basis for apprehending the defendant could make out any defence of justification (truth and public benefit), privilege or comment: Bonnard v Perryman [1891] 2 Ch 269 at 284; [1891-4] All ER Rep 965 ; Holley v Smyth [1998] QB 726 at 737–43; [1998] 1 All ER 853; [1998] 2 WLR 742 ; Cream Holdings Ltd v Banerjee [2003] Ch 650; [2003] 2 All ER 318; [2003] 3 WLR 999 at [43], [96] ; and

there is no real likelihood the plaintiff would only be awarded nominal damages: William Coulson & Sons v James Coulson & Co (1887) 3 TLR 846 ; Monson v Tussauds Ltd [1894] 1 QB 671; [1891–4] All ER Rep 1051 .

Because of the special principles that require consideration, any application to restrain an allegedly defamatory publication should be made to the Defamation List judge or, if that judge is unavailable, to the appropriate duty judge: Rural and General Insurance Ltd v Australian Broadcasting Corp (NSWSC, Bryson J, No 2416 of 1995, 15 June 1995, unreported, BC9504787) (inappropriate to apply in the Supreme Court to the Equity Division duty judge).

An application for a final injunction to restrain an allegedly defamatory publication cannot be granted without first determining whether the impugned publication is both defamatory and actionable. This requires giving the defendant the opportunity to contest the claim and resolution of any defences on which the defendant relies. A plaintiff’s disavowal of a claim for damages (on the basis of the defendant’s likely impecuniosity) does not provide a basis to resolve the claim for a final injunction on the basis of the principles that apply to the grant of an interlocutory injunction: Naoum v Danawi (2009) 75 NSWLR 216; [2009] NSWCA 253; BC200907592 .

As suggested in the preceding note, it is only in urgent cases that it is appropriate to make applications under this Part without prior notice to the opposing parties. If the court is not satisfied that the circumstances justify orders being made on an ex parte application, the court may simply abridge the time for, and make other orders to facilitate the filing and service of the originating process and application.

level.toc-caption: [25.1.50] Procedure on the return date of interim/ex parte orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.1.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 75.

heading.title: Procedure on the return date of interim/ex parte orders

p.text: Where interim orders have been made until the return date of the proceedings, one of four things usually happens on that return date:
The matter is settled;
The defendant gives a satisfactory undertaking to the court;
The defendant consents to the continuation of the orders — either for a limited period or until further order; or
The defendant contests the continuation of the orders.

If the defendant contests the continuation of the orders, the judge will usually deal with the matter on the return day. Again hearsay evidence is acceptable, subject to compliance with s 75 of the Evidence Act 1995; see also Disclosure Duty of Applicant for Interim Injunction (1999) 18 CJQ 193, at 195; National Australia Bank Ltd v Idoport Pty Ltd [2000] NSWCA 8; BC200000274 at [9] .

Because of the nature of the issue to be determined on an application for interim orders under this rule: see [25.1.35] above; it is not the function of the court to embark upon a preliminary determination of the matters in dispute: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560 : Transport Workers' Union of Australia (NSW Branch) v Leon Laidely Pty Ltd (1980) 28 ALR 589 at 600; 43 FLR 168 . For this reason it may not always be appropriate to allow cross-examination of the opposing witnesses. However, the matter is one for the discretion of the court having regard to the circumstances, and in particular the urgency, of the particular case: Ashburton Oil NL v Alpha Minerals NL (1971) 123 CLR 614 at 642 per Gibbs J. The court's control of procedures in relation to the grant of interim relief should not be restricted by inflexible rules of practice: Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428 .

An undertaking to the court has the same force as an injunction: see Biba Ltd v Stratford Investments Ltd [1973] Ch 281; [1972] 3 All ER 1041 . Accordingly counsel should not give an undertaking to the court unless clearly instructed so to do. Moreover, the client must be advised that an undertaking has the same force as an injunction and that breach of an undertaking may be punished by attachment or sequestration. An undertaking may be received notwithstanding that a court would have no power to grant an injunction in the same terms as the undertaking: Trade Practices Commission v APM Investments Pty Ltd (1983) ATPR ¶40-403 — subject to the undertaking being reasonably related to the orderly procedure of the court or to the subject matter of the litigation: Thomson Australian Holdings Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1981) 148 CLR 150; 37 ALR 66 at 76; BC8100114 . Although the APM case was reversed on appeal (APM Investments Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 49 ALR 475; ATPR ¶40-404 ), the point made above was unaffected. See also discussion of an undertaking as an alternative to an interlocutory injunction in I C F Spry, Equitable Remedies, 6th ed, Lawbook Co, Sydney, 2001, pp 478-81.

However, it is arguably more difficult to be relieved of an undertaking than it is to have an injunction discharged. See Cutler v Wandsworth Stadium Ltd [1945] 1 All ER 103 : see further [SCA s 66.10] .

Courts may vary any interlocutory order (see [36.16.35] and [36.16.60] , dealing with liberty to apply) and [SCA s 66.55] : Woods v Sheriff of Queensland (1895) 6 QLJ 163 ; Hutchinson v Nominal Defendant [1972] 1 NSWLR 443 ; Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170; 35 ALR 625; BC8100095 . Courts also have the power to release a party from an undertaking — whether or not there was an operative mistake at the time the undertaking was given, and even without the consent of the opposing party, see Cutler v Wandsworth Stadium Ltd [1945] 1 All ER 103 at 105 per Morton LJ; Chanel Ltd v FW Woolworth & Co Ltd [1981] 1 All ER 745; [1981] 1 WLR 485 . However, because of the undesirability of repeated interlocutory consideration of the same matters (see [25.1.80] ) the power would not normally be exercised unless there was some material change in circumstances. Variation of orders and undertakings is further discussed in [SCA s 66.55] . Variation of consent orders and undertakings is discussed in [36.16.40] and [SCA s 66.60] .

If it becomes apparent that the registry will have to issue a notice of orders made under this Part after the usual opening hours, advance notice should be given to the registry office by telephone as early as possible. A late opening fee in addition to the ordinary filing fee of initiating process, may be payable.
Legislation cited in [25.1.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.17.

If the judge grants the application and makes the orders sought, a request should be made to the judge’s associate for a copy of the judge’s notes of the orders. The notes are the basis for the formal notice of the orders that must be prepared and given to the defendant. The notice will be signed by the registrar and, subject to any specific order that has been made, the successful applicant must then arrange for service of the signed orders. If notice of the orders is to be served by letter pursuant to UCPR r 10.17 , a copy of the notice should be typed for signature by the registrar.

It is not appropriate to make merely repetitive applications, especially successive applications to different judges, for substantially the same interlocutory relief: Chanel Ltd v FW Woolworth & Co Ltd [1981] 1 All ER 745; [1981] 1 WLR 485 ; Re Delta Landscaping Pty Ltd (1990) 20 NSWLR 508 ; Brimaud v Honeysett Instant Print Pty Ltd (1988) 6 ACLC 942; BC8801632 (cited with approval in Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [1999] NSWCA 313 at [38]; BC9906206 ); Wentworth v Rogers (NSWSC, Sperling J, 28 April 1995, unreported, BC9507335); but see Nominal Defendant v Manning (2000) 50 NSWLR 139; 31 MVR 524; [2000] NSWCA 80; BC200005011 (second application to extend limitation period — unnecessary to impose rigid criteria against multiple interlocutory applications — but see Fletcher v Besser [2010] NSWCA 30; BC201001212 at [17]). A further application for interlocutory relief may be made if there has been a material change of circumstances or, perhaps, if a party has discovered significant new evidence that was not reasonably available at the time of the first application: Collier v Howard (NSWSC, McLelland CJ, 23 April 1996, unreported, BC9601420); Forbes v Lindop (NSWCA, Kirby ACJ, Clarke and Sheller JJA, 17 July 1995, unreported) (successive applications to set aside default judgment) cited with approval in State Rail Authority v Gaudron [1998] 9 Leg Rep SL 96; BC9703533; National Parks and Wildlife Service v Pierson (2002) 55 NSWLR 315; [2002] NSWCA 273; BC200204666 (further application to set aside judgment after remedying default).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.2] r 25.2 Order in urgent case before commencement of proceedings (cf SCR Part 28, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Order in urgent case before commencement of proceedings (cf SCR Part 28, rule 1)

p.text: In an urgent case, the court, on the application of a person who intends to commence proceedings, may do any of the following:
it may make any order which the court might make in proceedings on an application for a writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum,
it may make any order for the custody of a minor,
it may grant any injunctive relief, including relief in the nature of a freezing order under Division 2 (Mareva relief) or a search order under Division 3 (an Anton Piller order),
it may make an order extending the operation of a caveat under:
the Real Property Act 1900, or
the Offshore Minerals Act 1999, or
the Offshore Minerals Act 1994 of the Commonwealth,
it may appoint a receiver,
it may make an order for the detention, custody or preservation of property under rule 25.3,
to the same extent as if the applicant had commenced the proceedings and the application were made in the proceedings.
[subr (1) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 9 June 2006]

In relation to proceedings in the Supreme Court, an application under subrule (1) may be made in any division of the Court but must, so far as practicable, be made in the division to which the proceedings that are intended to be commenced would be assigned.

A person making an application under subrule (1) must give an undertaking to the court to the effect that the applicant will file originating process commencing the proceedings within such time as the court may order or, if the court makes no such order, within 48 hours after the application is granted.

Injunctive relief operates in personam and the jurisdiction to grant it depends upon the defendant being subject to the court's process. There is power to grant injunctive relief against a defendant who is within the jurisdiction even though they are ordinarily resident abroad or where the acts restrained, or sought to be performed, would occur outside the jurisdiction: Companhia de Mocambique v British South Africa Co [1892] 2 QB 358 at 364 ; Penn v Baltimore (1750) 1 Ves sen 444; 27 ER 1132 (property situate abroad); Toller v Carteret (1705) 2 Vern 494; 23 ER 916 (foreclosure of a foreign mortgage); Lord Portarlington v Soulby (1834) 3 My & K 104 at 108; 40 ER 40; similarly injunctive relief may be ordered against a foreign defendant who has submitted to the jurisdiction: Drummond v Drummond (1866) LR 2 Ch App 32 at 43; or who is properly served outside the jurisdiction: Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210; [1977] 3 All ER 803 . However, the granting of relief is always discretionary and the court will take into account the question of the most convenient forum, as well as the difficulty or impossibility of enforcement of the order: Cammell v Cammell [1965] P 467 at 472; Waterhouse v Stansfield (1851) 9 Hare 234; 68 ER 489 ; Grey v Manitoba and North-Western Railway Co of Canada [1897] AC 254 ; Bank of Africa v Cohen [1909] 2 Ch 129 ; Tallack v Tallack (1927) P 211. Where the defendant is ordinarily resident abroad, but has property within the jurisdiction, it is proper to take that factor into account since the court's orders could be enforced by sequestration and attachment: Hospital for Sick Children v Walt Disney Productions Inc [1968] Ch 52 ; Hunter v Hunter [1962] P 1 at 6 and see also Spry on Equitable Remedies 3rd ed, pp 43–4.
Legislation cited in [25.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 [SCA s 75.10].

It will rarely be appropriate to grant an interlocutory injunction in mandatory terms: Parker v Camden London Borough Council [1986] 1 Ch 162; Harold Stephen & Co Ltd v Post Office [1977] 1 WLR 1172 and there is authority to suggest that where a mandatory interlocutory injunction is sought the court must be satisfied both that there is a real question to be tried and also that there is a high degree of assurance that the plaintiff will ultimately succeed at the trial: Queensland v Australian Telecommunications Commission (1985) 59 ALR 243; 59 ALJR 562 ; Shepherd Homes Ltd v Sandham [1971] Ch 340 at 351 ; Midland Milk v Victorian Dairy Industry Authority (1987) 82 ALR 279 . However, the true position may be that, notwithstanding an understandable reluctance to grant mandatory interlocutory relief, the court ought to grant relief of that kind whenever it is satisfied that refusing the relief would carry a greater risk of injustice than granting the order sought: Tsimidopoulos v Mulson Holdings Pty Ltd [1989] WAR 359; Films Rover International Ltd v Cannon Film Sales Ltd [1986] 3 All ER 772 ; Fletcher Challenge Ltd v Fletcher Challenge Pty Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 196 at 207–8 ; Businessworld Computers Pty Ltd v Australian Telecommunications Commission (1988) 15 ALD 479; 82 ALR 499 . Where the proposed injunction would have a profound effect upon a defendant, such as, for example, where it would expose the defendant to the risk of significant costs or losses, the court should be satisfied, to a relatively high degree, of the appropriateness of the order in the particular circumstances: Racecourse Totalisators Pty Ltd v Totalisator Administration Board of Queensland (1995) 58 FCR 119 ; Active Leisure (Sports) Pty Ltd v Sportsman’s Australia Ltd [1991] 1 Qd R 301 . The court may be more willing to grant an interim mandatory order where its practical effect will be not to cause the defendant to take a new course of action but rather to revert to the position that prevailed before the events which prompted the litigation: Redland Bricks Ltd v Morris [1970] AC 652; [1969] 2 All ER 576 ; Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 24, [948].

If issues of interpretation subsequently arise in relation to the meaning and scope of the order, it may be appropriate to bring proceedings for a declaration as to the effect of the order, rather than pursuing the question of arguable non-compliance as contempt: see Blanch (t/as Hicksons) v British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd (2005) 62 NSWLR 653; [2005] NSWSC 241; BC200501638 and [36.16.72] and [SCA s 75.10] .

Any injunction should be clearly expressed and state what parties affected by them are bound to do, or refrain from doing: Australian Federation of Construction Contractors v Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders' Labourers' Federation (1984) 73 FLR 61 at 62 . Where the court is asked to grant an interlocutory injunction it is particularly important that the order be framed in such a way that the defendant can identify as a matter of fact: Redland Bricks Ltd v Morris [1970] AC 652; [1969] 2 All ER 576 ; what they must, or must not, do: Optus Networks Pty Ltd v City of Boroondara [1997] 2 VR 318; (1996) 136 FLR 117; BC9606102 . In exceptional cases the inability to frame an appropriate form of order may lead to the failure of the application for interlocutory relief: Greetings Oxford Koala Hotel Pty Ltd v Oxford Square Investments Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 33 (no interim mandatory injunction to enforce a contractual obligation to repair).

Accordingly both principle and the practical considerations (ie, the difficulty of enforcing or defending contempt proceedings) suggest that any injunction should generally be confined to the conduct which has been alleged (and in the case of a final injunction, established) as contravening the plaintiff's rights: Redland Bricks Ltd v Morris [1970] AC 652 at 666–7; [1969] 2 All ER 576 (final mandatory injunction — order to take all necessary steps to restore support to land — insufficiently precise); Iberian Trust Ltd v Founders Trust and Investment Co Ltd [1932] 2 KB 87 (final order that defendant do have a return of shares within 14 days — imprecise); Animal Liberation (Vic) Inc v Gasser [1991] 1 VR 51 at 57 (interim injunction restraining demonstrations — insufficiently precise); Optus Networks Pty Ltd v City of Boroondara [1997] 2 VR 318; (1996) 136 FLR 117; BC9606102 (interlocutory injunction restraining any works — insufficiently precise); Nexus Mortgage Securities Pty Ltd v Ecto Pty Ltd [1998] 4 VR 220; BC9800610 (interlocutory injunction restraining sale by mortgagee – imprecise as to duration and property affected); ICI v Trade Practices Commission (1992) 38 FCR 248 at 259 , (injunctions should be in plain and unambiguous terms) (injunction restraining conduct alleged in the statement of claim — sufficiently precise).

The general principles requiring certainty are subject to limitations of practicality and commonsense: Curro v Beyond Productions Pty Ltd (1993) 30 NSWLR 337 at 349 Meagher, Handley and Cripps JJA. In this respect there is said to be a fundamental difference between, on the one hand, orders that are impermissibly uncertain in the scope of the obligations they impose and, on the other hand, orders which require the addressee to achieve a particular result but permit a degree of choice about the manner by which the result is achieved: Concrete Constructions Pty Ltd v Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees' Union (No 2) (1987) 15 FCR 64; 72 ALR 415 . Where the orders are of the latter kind, provided an order specifies the result that compliance is intended to achieve it is not normally for the applicant to suggest, nor the court to prescribe, the particular conduct required to achieve the desired result: Concrete Constructions Pty Ltd v Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees' Union (No 2) (1987) 15 FCR 64; 72 ALR 415 (order prohibiting enforcement of union bans relating to a building site — sufficiently precise); Bankstown City Council v Alamdo Holdings Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 325; BC200406123 (injunction restraining discharge of stormwater so as to cause a nuisance — sufficiently precise); Maggbury Pty Ltd v Hafele Australia Pty Ltd (2001) 210 CLR 181 at 220 per Callinan J (excessively narrow formalism in framing the injunction may wreak its own injustice); Trade Practices Commission v Glo Juice Co Pty Ltd (1986) 73 ALR 407 at 415, 417–418 (injunction framed to require compliance with a procedure rather than a result standard).

In the case of interlocutory injunctions the exigencies of the situation may permit an unavoidable degree of imprecision: Greetings Oxford Koala Hotel Pty Ltd v Oxford Square Investments Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 33 at 41 . But if the plaintiff's allegations involve material ambiguity about the content and scope of the plaintiff's rights, the injunction should attempt a reasonably precise limitation of the conduct proscribed: PA Thomas & Co v Mould [1968] 2 QB 913 (interlocutory injunction restraining publication of confidential information — insufficiently precise); World Series Cricket Pty Ltd v Parish (1977) 16 ALR 181 at 191; (1977) ATPR ¶40-040 (interlocutory injunction restraining misleading and deceptive conduct — insufficiently precise); Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan (1965) 112 CLR 483 at 504 and 515–516; [1966] ALR 387; BC6500220 (interlocutory injunction restraining publication of material in respect of which the plaintiff has copyright — insufficiently precise, because the scope of copyright was undetermined); Cother v Midland Railway Co (1848) 17 LJ Ch 235 (injunction restraining entry onto land otherwise than for the necessary purposes of the railway — insufficiently precise).
Legislation cited in [25.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 67.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 26.

Specific powers in relation to the appointment of receivers are contained in s 67 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 and in Pt 26 of the UCPR. This Part deals with the exercise of those powers on an urgent application before the commencement of proceedings. Essentially the same principles apply to both ex parte applications for injunctions and to applications for the appointment of a receiver. In particular, an undertaking as to damages should normally be required: National Australia Bank Ltd v Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 271; 92 ALR 49; BC9002915 . Care should be taken to distinguish situations where an injunction is required from those where the appropriate remedy is the appointment of a receiver. For example, in a partnership dispute, the court will not ordinarily grant an injunction against one of the former partners. The more usual course will be to appoint a receiver of the partnership business.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.3] r 25.3 Preservation of property (cf SCR Part 28, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Preservation of property (cf SCR Part 28, rule 2)

p.text: In proceedings concerning property, or in which any question may arise as to property, the court may make orders for the detention, custody or preservation of the property.
An order under subrule (1) may authorise any person to enter any land or to do any other thing for the purpose of giving effect to the order.
In proceedings concerning the right of any party to a fund, the court may order that the fund be paid into court or otherwise secured.

This court may make an order that the property be held by the court pending the hearing. This is an aspect of preservation. Orders have been made that banknotes (Campbell v Brownless), jewellery (Velati & Co v Braham & Co (1877) 46 LJCP 415; Ridpath v Zachner (1893) 9 TLR 538) are within the rule. It must be shown that the party against whom the order is sought has possession of the property: Wilder v Wilder (1912) 56 Sol Jo 571.

The preservation orders that may be made under this Part are limited to the “detention, custody or preservation of property” about which a question arises in the proceedings. Consequently, no such preservation orders may be made under this Part where the particular property has already been converted into money: Pizzey Properties Pty Ltd v Edelstein [1977] VR 161 ; approved in Wentworth v Rogers (No 8) (1986) 7 NSWLR 207 . Neither does the Part apply where the property is not the subject matter of the proceedings: Wentworth v Rogers (No 8) (order sought in relation to funds deposited with a party’s solicitor).

“Property” in this rule includes a document: Re Saxton (dec’d); Johnson v Saxton [1962] 3 All ER 92; [1962] 1 WLR 968 ; Re Saxton (dec’d); Johnson v Saxton [1962] 2 All ER 618; [1962] 1 WLR 859 . If there is a danger that documents, either in the possession of a stranger or the opposing party, will be lost or removed from the jurisdiction, the court may order their production: Hyland v AGC (Wholesale) Pty Ltd [1983] 1 VR 222 ; Norwich Pharmacal Co v Customs and Excise Cmrs [1974] AC 133; [1973] 2 All ER 943 ; British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417 .

The rule applies whenever there is a need to secure or protect property. In the exercise of its powers under this rule the court is not required to embark upon an investigation of the merits of the parties' competing claims: Campbell v Brownless (1901) 26 VLR 609 at 611 ; Johnson v Tobacco Leaf Marketing Board [1967] VR 427 at 430 . The usual methods of preservation are injunction, or appointment of a receiver. Thus in England orders have been made that a receiver be appointed of a licence and possession of a hotel be given to the receiver: Charrington & Co Ltd v Camp [1902] 1 Ch 386 ; Leney & Sons Ltd v Callingham [1908] 1 KB 79 . But the rule gives the court a wide power to make any appropriate preservation order — even against a party who has a proprietary interest in the property: Johnson v Tobacco Leaf Marketing Board , above at 433–4. The power includes orders requiring carrying out of necessary repairs: Steamship New Orleans Co v London and Provincial Marine and General Insurance Co [1909] 1 KB 943 (order made on the application of a defendant insurer that a ship be repaired at the defendant's expense and returned to London). However, it does not go further than what is necessary to preserve the property: Centre Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Services Pty Ltd v Lincoln (1983) 70 FLR 200 . It does not extend, for example, to the making of orders for the payment of debts owing to a mortgagee: Taggart v Gaston (No 2) (1990) DFC 95–098. Neither does it extend to the preservation of a wasting asset: Seminara v Ferguson (1993) 16 Fam LR 410; BC9302035 (motor vehicle). A manufacturing process does not constitute property: for the purpose of the rule: Tudor Accumulator Co Ltd v China Mutual Steam Navigation Co Ltd [1930] WN 200 .

Apart from the specific provisions of the present rule, the Supreme Court has an inherent equitable jurisdiction to protect the safety of title deeds, see Leathes v Leathes (1877) 5 Ch D 221 at 223 and W E Grigsby, Commentaries on Equity Jurisprudence, 1st English ed, 1892, London, section 704.

The power conferred by UCPR r 25.3(3) (to order payment into court) depends on the existence of a disputed fund. The fund must have some separate and distinct existence as an item of tangible property. Neither a mere debt, nor a disputed contractual entitlement, constitute a “fund” to which the rule applies: Newcastle City Council v Caverstock Group Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 249; BC200808948 (disputed claim under a bank guarantee – proceeds held in general bank account – no fund); Myers v Design Inc (International) Ltd [2003] 1 All ER 1168; [2003] 1 WLR 1642; [2003] EWHC 103 (Ch) (debt did not constitute a “specified fund”).
The principles that apply to orders dealing with the payment of moneys that have been paid into court are dealt with in [43.7.10] & [55.11.5].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.4] r 25.4 Disposal of personal property (cf SCR Part 28, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Disposal of personal property (cf SCR Part 28, rule 3)

p.text: If, in proceedings concerning property (other than land) or in which any question may arise as to any property (other than land), it appears to the court that:
the property is of a perishable nature or is likely to deteriorate, or
for any other reason it is desirable that the property should be sold or otherwise disposed of,
the court may make an order for the sale or other disposal of the whole or any part of the property by such person, and in such manner, as the court may direct.

The power under this rule is only available as ancillary to some other appropriate form of relief claimed in the proceedings: Ryan v King [1932] QWN 1 ; McDonald v McDonald [1948] QWN 47 ; Jacobson v Jacobson [1953] VLR 177 ; Ferrari v Beccaris [1979] 2 NSWLR 181.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.5] r 25.5 Interim distribution (cf SCR Part 28, rule 4)

p.text: If, in proceedings concerning property, it appears to the court that the property is more than sufficient to answer the claims on the property for which provision ought to be made in the proceedings, the court may allow any part of the property to be conveyed, transferred or delivered to any person having an interest in the property.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.6] r 25.6 Interim income (cf SCR Part 28, rule 5)

p.text: If, in proceedings concerning property, it appears to the court that the whole or any part of the income of the property is not required to answer the claims on the property or its income for which provision ought to be made in the proceedings, the court may allow that income or part to be paid, during such period as the court may determine, to all or any of the persons having an interest in the income.

An order under the present rule will only be made in a clear case of excess where the proceedings cannot be disposed of within a reasonable time or there is some other pressing reason: Rowley v Burgess (1854) 2 WR 652.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.7] r 25.7 Payment before ascertainment of all persons interested (cf SCR Part 28, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Payment before ascertainment of all persons interested (cf SCR Part 28, rule 6)

p.text: If two or more persons are entitled to share in a fund, the court may order or allow immediate payment to any of those persons of his or her share without reserving any part of that share to meet the subsequent costs of ascertaining any other of those persons.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.8] r 25.8 Meaning of ″usual undertaking as to damages″ (cf SCR Part 28, rule 7(2))

leg:heading.title: Meaning of "usual undertaking as to damages" (cf SCR Part 28, rule 7(2))

p.text: The "usual undertaking as to damages", if given to the court in connection with any interlocutory order or undertaking, is an undertaking to the court to submit to such order (if any) as the court may consider to be just for the payment of compensation (to be assessed by the court or as it may direct) to any person (whether or not a party) affected by the operation of the interlocutory order or undertaking or of any interlocutory continuation (with or without variation) of the interlocutory order or undertaking.
Legislation cited in [25.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 26, r 25.2(1)(e), r 25.8.
(NSW) Real Property Act 1900 s 74K.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 440C.

The court will usually require the plaintiff who obtains an injunction, or who is given an undertaking in lieu of an injunction, to give the usual undertaking as to damages in accordance with UCPR r 25.8 . The court cannot compel the giving of an undertaking but it may, and in some cases should (National Australia Bank Ltd v Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 271; 92 ALR 49; BC9002915 ; National Australia Bank Ltd v Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd [1991] 1 VR 386 ) refuse the application for interlocutory relief unless the undertaking is offered (Tucker v New Brunswick Trading Co of London (1890) 44 Ch D 249 ; Kerridge v Foley [1968] 1 NSWR 628; (1968) 88 WN (NSW) 63 ; Frigo v Culhaci (NSWCA, 17 July 1998, unreported, BC9803225) at pp 12–15).

In any ordinary case, giving an undertaking as to damages is, in effect, the price that an applicant for interim relief must be prepared to pay in order to obtain the orders sought: Kerridge v Foley [1968] 1 NSWR 628; (1968) 88 WN (NSW) 63 ; Chisholm v Rieff (1953) 2 FLR 211 and Air Express Ltd v Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd (1981) 146 CLR 249 at 260 and 311; 33 ALR 578; BC8100053 ; Australian Marketing Development Pty Ltd v Australian Interstate Marketing Pty Ltd [1972] VR 219 at 229 ; Chisholm v Rieff, above; Smith v Day (1882) 21 Ch D 421 . Consistent with that general justification, an undertaking as to damages may be required whether the claim arises under the general law or from a particular statutory provision — such as a claim for the extension of a caveat (under Real Property Act 1900 s 74K ) or a claim restraining re-entry on property leased by a company in administration: Acqualounge Manly Pty Ltd v Barecall Pty Ltd (2005) 222 ALR 384; [2005] NSWSC 627; BC200504691 (claim under Corporations Act 2001 s 440C ). As to applications for the appointment of a receiver see UCPR r 25.2(1)(e) and Pt 26 .

heading.title: Persons required to give an undertaking

p.text: Differing views have been expressed as to whether an undertaking should be required of a statutory authority bringing proceedings to enforce compliance with a statutory obligation: Kirklees MBC v Wickes Building Supplies Ltd [1993] AC 227; [1992] 3 All ER 717 (no undertaking required of a public authority enforcing a statutory duty); Optus Networks Pty Ltd v City of Boroondara [1997] 2 VR 318; (1996) 136 FLR 117; BC9606102 (undertaking normally required).

The Crown may be required to provide an undertaking as to damages — at least when it is suing to protect its proprietary rights: Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113 ; Secretary of State for Trade and Industry v Hoffmann-La Roche & Co AG [1975] AC 295 at 361; [1973] 3 All ER 945 ; Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Giraffe World Australia Pty Ltd (1998) 84 FCR 512; 156 ALR 273; [1998] FCA 819; BC9803246 (undertaking required where Mareva order sought).

The ability of a party to honour any undertaking as to damages is a relevant consideration on any application for interim relief: American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 408; [1975] 1 All ER 504 ; Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd v Surfers Paradise Forests Ltd [1977] Qd R 261 ; Active Leisure (Sports) Pty Ltd v Sportsman’s Australia Ltd [1991] 1 Qd R 301 . An application for interlocutory relief may be refused if the plaintiff’s undertaking is likely to prove ineffective — either because of difficulties the defendant could be expected to encounter in attempting to establish a causal connection between the order asked to be made and any subsequent loss or because of the plaintiff’s lack of means: Air Express Ltd v Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd (1981) 146 CLR 249; 33 ALR 578; BC8100053 ; Carlton & United Breweries (NSW) Pty Ltd v Bond Brewing (NSW) Ltd (1987) 76 ALR 633 at 640 . The court retains a discretion to grant interim relief notwithstanding a real risk the undertaking could prove inadequate. But the nature of the discretion involved in granting interim relief, strongly suggests that special circumstances would have to exist before it would be appropriate to dispense with a requirement for the plaintiff to provide meaningful security: Varley v Varley [2006] NSWSC 1025 at [45]–[67] (relevant impecuniosity) — discussing Blue Seas Investments Pty Ltd v Victor Mitchell (1999) 25 Fam LR 65 ; Allen v Jambo Holdings [1980] 1 WLR 1252 ; Szentessy v Woo Ran (1985) 64 ACTR 98 at 104 ; Dein & Dein v Bealy [1960] NSWR 385 (injunction of very limited duration).

heading.title: Evidence and disclosure of lack of capacity to honour the undertaking

p.text: The court will normally assume, in the absence of contrary information, that a party has the capacity to meet any undertaking it proffers: Manor Electronics Ltd v Dickson [1988] RPC 618 ; Swedac Ltd v Magnet & Southern Plc [1989] FSR 243 at 251. But there is no formal presumption in favour of a party’s capacity to meet an undertaking. Where there is a reason for doubt, the ability of a party to honour the undertaking should be the subject of evidence. In the case of an ex parte application, an applicant’s duty of candour will extend to require disclosure of circumstances relevant to its capacity to honour any undertaking as to damages: Lock International Plc v Beswick [1989] 1 WLR 1268 .

If the court is not satisfied about an applicant’s financial capacity it may require security to support the undertaking: Select Personnel Pty Ltd v Morgan & Banks Pty Ltd (1988) 12 IPR 167 ; Re DPR Futures Ltd [1989] 1 WLR 778 at 786 ; Commodity Ocean Transport v Basford Unicorn [1987] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 197. Security may be required either from the applicant or a third party. The security may take the form of a payment into court (Jones v Pacaya Rubber & Produce Co [1911] 1 KB 455 ; Lister v Cowdrey (1900) 21 LR (NSW) Eq 4) payment to a stakeholder (Baxter v Clayton [1952] WN 376) or an unconditional guarantee from a financial institution.

The rule clearly envisages that non-parties may be affected by the operation of an interlocutory injunction and may have a subsequent entitlement to claim damages. However, it has been held that the potential impact of an interlocutory injunction, for example, upon an innocent third party purchaser, is relevant only to the question whether the balance of convenience favours the granting of the injunction: Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd v South Australia (1986) 161 CLR 148 at 153; 67 ALR 553 ; Kolback Securities Ltd v Epoch Mining NL (1987) 8 NSWLR 533; 11 ACLR 630 ; Silktone Pty Ltd v Devreal Capital Pty Ltd (1990) 21 NSWLR 317 .

The potential ability for a defendant to recover damages pursuant to an undertaking as to damages arises whenever the plaintiff’s claim ultimately fails. It is not limited to cases where an interlocutory injunction has been wrongly obtained: Air Express Ltd v Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd (1981) 146 CLR 249 at 261; 33 ALR 578; BC8100053 ; Griffith v Blake (1884) 27 Ch D 474 ; cf Smith v Day (1882) 21 Ch D 421 . However, because the undertaking as to damages is given to the court it does not confer any separate cause of action upon the other parties to the proceedings. The court retains a discretion whether to enforce the undertaking, but will not ordinarily refuse to do so: Evans of Robb Evans and Associates v European Bank Ltd (2009) 255 ALR 171; [2009] NSWCA 67; BC200902235 at [47]–[55], [116] ; Coshott v Principal Strategic Options Pty Ltd [2004] FCAFC 50; BC200401056 at [18] . Damages are recoverable for the natural consequences of granting the injunction in the particular circumstances: Air Express Ltd v Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd (1981) 146 CLR 249 at 267, 310 per Barwick CJ, at 312 per Gibbs J, at 317 per Stephen J, at 324 per Mason J; 33 ALR 578; BC8100053 (no damages for failure to obtain licence to acquire aircraft). They will extend to include damages of a kind that were foreseeable as a possible consequence of granting the injunction. European Bank Ltd v Evans of Robb Evans and Associates (2010) 240 CLR 432; 264 ALR 1; [2010] HCA 6; BC201001148 (damages recoverable for loss of profit on foreseeable foreign exchange transaction); Moraitis Fresh Packaging (NSW) Pty Ltd v Fresh Express Australia Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 704; BC201004576 (damages recoverable for loss of opportunity to sell subject-matter of the undertaking/injunction). See also the article by I Spry (1991) 65 ALJ 658 as to whether the court’s power to award damages relating to the grant of an interlocutory injunction is dependent upon the plaintiff having given the usual undertaking.

The court retains a discretion whether to enforce the undertaking, but will ordinarily do so unless there are special circumstances: Evans of Robb Evans and Associates v European Bank Ltd (2009) 255 ALR 171; [2009] NSWCA 67; BC200902235 at [47]–[55], [116] ; Coshott v Principal Strategic Options Pty Ltd [2004] FCAFC 50; BC200401056 at [18] : see [25.8.20] . Special circumstances may include:
delay in enforcing the undertaking: ex parte Hall; in re Wood (1883) 23 Ch D 644 (4 year delay);
the smallness of the amount claimed: Smith v Day (1882) 21 Ch D 421 at 425 ;
where a delayed application was made by third parties after the resolution of the proceedings between the parties: Clift v Windrum [1991] NSWCA 54; BC9101602 ;

where the proceedings raise issues of public interest and the defendant has failed to obtain an order for costs or has engaged in delinquent conduct: Cheltenham & Gloucester Building Society v Ricketts [1993] 1 WLR 1545 at 1557 ; and

where the judgment favouring the defendant was obtained by fraud, or, perhaps where the original order could have been sustained on other grounds not raised in the proceedings: McCleary v DPP (Cth) (1998) 20 WAR 288; 157 ALR 301 at 322; BC9803315 (undertaking given under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 (Cth).
Legislation cited in [25.8.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.8.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 28 r 7.

The usual form of undertaking has varied from time to time. One of its earliest forms in New South Wales is contained in Cooper v Smyth (1883) 4 LR (NSW) Eq 39 at 41 . By 1902 the practice was that the undertaking extended to all defendants and not just to those who were subject to the injunction: Rich, Newham and Harvey, The Practice in Equity, p 19. The Practice Direction of 9 March 1971 was to a similar effect. Prior to r 25.8 the form of the usual undertaking as to damages was set out in former SCR Pt 28 r 7 . The undertaking provided for in r 25.8 permits non-parties to obtain the benefit of the undertaking in an appropriate case. Although even without the present rule it was within the court's power to entertain applications from non-parties who were adversely affected by an injunction: Cretanor Maritime Co Ltd v Irish Marine Management Ltd [1978] 3 All ER 164 at 174 ; and to require that any undertaking as to damages be expressed so as to be available to the affected non-parties: Smith Kline & French Laboratories (Aust) Ltd v Secretary, Dept of Community Services (1989) 89 ALR 366 at 371 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.9] r 25.9 Orders may be made at any stage of proceedings (cf SCR Part 28, rule 7(1))

leg:heading.title: Orders may be made at any stage of proceedings (cf SCR Part 28, rule 7(1))

p.text: Orders may be made under this Part at any stage of proceedings.
Legislation cited in [25.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 67.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 66(4).

In addition to the specific provisions of the Rules dealing with the stay of proceedings pending an appeal (see s 67 of the CPA), the court may also make orders designed either to preserve property, or the (contested) rights of the parties pending an appeal. That power may be attributed either to s 66(4) of the Supreme Court Act 1970 or to the court’s incidental or inherent jurisdiction: see [51.44.5] ; Paringa Mining and Exploration Co Plc v North Flinders Mines Ltd (No 2) (1988) 165 CLR 452; 81 ALR 609 — see further [51.44.5] .
